Award.AwardTitle: CBMS Conference: Reflectionless measures, Wolff's potentials, and rectifiability, June 15-19, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the NSF/CBMS regional conference, which will be held at North Dakota State University in the summer of 2015, on the David-Semmes conjecture, a problem that has been open for almost twenty-five years and that provides a connection between complex analysis, harmonic analysis and geometric measure theory. In 2012, the codimension one case of the conjecture was proven by two independent research teams using different techniques, sparking a renewed interest on the problem and a series of new publications. The goal of this conference is to bring together several experts in this area, have them introduce the problem and its most recent developments to junior researchers, and foster new collaborations with the aim of proving the full conjecture. The main lectures will be delivered by Professor Fedor Nazarov, of Kent State University, and written in a monograph which will collect all the developments on the conjecture from the last decade.

The main topic of the lectures is the David--Semmes conjecture, which aims to provide a geometric description of the measures that have bounded singular potentials for Calderon-Zygmund kernels. The very recent developments on Riesz transforms and rectifiability, which have culminated in the solution of the codimension one case of the conjecture, use techniques from several areas of analysis, such as non-homogeneous T1-type theorems from harmonic analysis, geometric symmetrization techniques, extremal problems of potential theory, Corona-type theorems from complex analysis. These techniques and their concrete use in the David-Semmes conjecture will be introduced in the conference to junior researchers, and there will be ample opportunities for discussion of the state of the problem led by the experts. The video-taped lectures will allow to reach a broader audience, and the resulting monograph will be an excellent introduction to the topic for new researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference "Reflectionless measures, Wolff potentials, and rectifiability" was held at North Dakota State University on July 27-31, 2015. The ten main lectures were delivered by Fedor Nazarov (Kent State University), whose contributions to Analysis have been recognized by honors including the Salem prize.

Nazarov's ten lectures focused on the problem of the geometric description of the measures that have bounded singular potentials for Calderon-Zygmund kernels. These problems lie on the boundary between Harmonic Analysis, Geometric Measure theory, and Complex Analysis. The main speaker provided a solid introduction to the area. Additionally, six talks by the invited speakers provided additional insight on the problem from different perspectives. The invited speakers were Guy David (Université Paris-Sud), José María Martell (ICMAT, Madrid), Pertti Mattila (University of Helsinki), Xavier Tolsa (ICREA-Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona), Sergei Treil (Brown University) and Alexander Volberg (Michigan State University).

Question and Answer Sessions provided participants with the opportunity to ask for clarification of some of the topics from the main lectures,and go into deeper detail. There was also ample time and classroom space for participants to discuss among themselves.

The video-recorded lecture series has been posted online, to make the talks and discussions available beyond the group of participants. Twenty-four of the forty six participants were graduate students with an interest on the topic, who found the series very valuable for their professional development. Isaac DeFrain, a graduate student at Kent State University) wrote "The conference was wonderful! All lectures were paced so well that even someone who does not specialize in the area, like me, could follow. Not to mention, there were so many great mathematicians there to bounce ideas off of. I learned so much and met so many great people!" Jonas Azzam, a postdoc at Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, wrote: "The conference was great. Not only did I learn from the seminars that were given, it was a great opportunity to meet with my collaborators to discuss our work and to meet new mathematicians." Sean Li (University of Chicago) wrote: "I really liked how the main lecture series began from a very simple starting point so that we could see how all the techniques are used to build up the result.  It was very enlightening."
